text.headline: The Birth of the Artificial Neuron
text.text: Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts published 'A Logical Calculus of the Ideas Immanent in Nervous Activity.' By creating a mathematical model of a biological neuron, they proved that even simple networks could compute any logical function, providing the theoretical foundation for all modern neural networks.

text.headline: Computing Machinery and Intelligence
text.text: Alan Turing published his seminal paper proposing the 'Imitation Game.' Rather than asking 'Can machines think?', he proposed a functional test: if a human evaluator cannot reliably distinguish a machine from a human through text conversation, the machine is said to exhibit intelligent behavior.

text.headline: The Dartmouth Workshop
text.text: John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Nathaniel Rochester, and Claude Shannon organized a summer research project where the term 'Artificial Intelligence' was first coined. The workshop established AI as a distinct academic field, predicated on the belief that every aspect of learning or intelligence can be precisely described and simulated by a machine.

text.headline: Unimate: Robotics Hits the Assembly Line
text.text: The first industrial robot, Unimate, joined the General Motors assembly line in New Jersey. Controlled by a magnetic drum, the 4,000-pound arm performed dangerous tasks like die-casting and welding, marking the first time AI-adjacent automation fundamentally transformed global manufacturing.

media.caption: Unimate serves drinks to Unimation cofounders Joseph Engelberger (left) and George Devol.

text.headline: ELIZA: The First Chatbot
text.text: Joseph Weizenbaum created ELIZA at MIT to explore Natural Language Processing. Its 'DOCTOR' script simulated a Rogerian psychotherapist by reflecting user input back as questions. Despite its simplicity, ELIZA famously demonstrated how easily humans attribute human-like emotions to machines—a phenomenon now known as the 'ELIZA Effect.'

media.caption: A screenshot of an ELIZA conversation.

text.headline: Shakey: The First 'Reasoning' Robot
text.text: Developed at SRI International, Shakey was the first mobile robot to combine computer vision with natural language processing and problem-solving. It could break down complex commands into a series of smaller, logical steps to navigate its environment using the A* search algorithm.

text.headline: The AI Winter
text.text: Following the 1966 ALPAC report and the 1973 Lighthill Report, AI research entered cycles of deep skepticism. Funding collapsed as early promises of machine translation and general intelligence failed to materialize, shifting focus away from 'thinking machines' toward more specialized, rule-based 'Expert Systems.'

media.caption: Visual representation of the AI Winter period.

text.headline: Deep Blue's Grandmaster Victory
text.text: IBM’s Deep Blue defeated world champion Garry Kasparov in a six-game match. While largely relying on 'brute-force' processing power to evaluate 200 million positions per second, the victory was a landmark moment for machine logic and a major PR win for the resurgence of AI.

text.headline: Roomba: Household Autonomy
text.text: iRobot introduced the Roomba, representing the first successful mass-market application of autonomous robotics. Using basic sensors to map floor space and avoid obstacles, it moved AI out of labs and into millions of homes, normalizing the presence of 'smart' domestic assistants.

media.caption: An original-generation Roomba.
media.credit: © 2006 Larry D. Moore. Licensed under CC BY 4.0.

text.headline: Siri and Watson: AI Goes Mainstream
text.text: 2011 marked a shift toward Big Data. IBM’s Watson defeated all-time champions on Jeopardy!, demonstrating 'Question Answering' capabilities across vast datasets. Simultaneously, Apple launched Siri, making voice-controlled AI a standard feature of personal computing.

text.headline: The Eugene Goostman Controversy
text.text: A chatbot portraying a 13-year-old Ukrainian boy reportedly 'passed' the Turing Test at the Royal Society. While controversial and criticized for using a persona to excuse its errors, the event sparked a global debate on whether Turing’s criteria were still a sufficient measure of intelligence.

text.headline: AlphaGo and Deep Reinforcement Learning
text.text: Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo defeated 18-time world champion Lee Sedol in Go. Unlike Deep Blue's brute force, AlphaGo used Deep Neural Networks and reinforcement learning to master a game with more possible positions than atoms in the observable universe, signaling the dawn of the Deep Learning era.

media.caption: Lee Sedol faces AlphaGo during the 2016 match.

text.headline: The ChatGPT Paradigm Shift
text.text: OpenAI released ChatGPT, a Large Language Model (LLM) based on the Transformer architecture. Its ability to generate human-like text and code triggered a global race in Generative AI, fundamentally altering the landscape of education, work, and technology.

text.headline: Sora: AI as a World Simulator
text.text: OpenAI revealed Sora, a text-to-video model capable of generating realistic, minute-long scenes with complex camera motion and multiple characters. This marked a major step toward building AI that understands and simulates the physical laws of the world.

media.caption: A demonstration of AI-generated cinematic video.

text.headline: The EU AI Act Enters Into Force
text.text: The European Union’s AI Act became the world's first comprehensive legal framework for AI. By adopting a risk-based approach—banning certain high-risk practices while regulating others—it set a global benchmark for the responsible development and governance of AI technology.

media.caption: The EU AI Act logo or legal seal.

text.headline: AlphaFold: AI Solves Biology's Grand Challenge
text.text: DeepMind's AlphaFold 2 solves the 50-year-old 'protein folding problem,' predicting the 3D shapes of proteins with near-experimental accuracy. In 2022, they released 200 million structures for free, accelerating drug discovery and enzyme engineering by decades. The breakthrough led to a 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for its creators.

media.caption: AlphaFold: Mapping the building blocks of life.

text.headline: The Rise of Agentic AI
text.text: In 2025, the focus shifted from 'chatbots' to 'agents.' These AI systems can autonomously plan multi-step tasks, use software tools, and operate computers to achieve complex goals, moving closer to the vision of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) through autonomous agency.

media.caption: Conceptual art of autonomous AI agents working together.
